topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Overview
topic.shortdesc: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is a high-performance, high-availability, cloud operating system based on OpenStack Kilo that enables telecommunications operators to use Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware to manage Virtualized Network Functions (VNF) within a carrier grade Network Function Virtualization (NFV) architecture.

body.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade brings together the flexibility and scalability of the IT cloud, and the high-availability and performance demanded by the Telecommunications industry, into a unique carrier grade, industry-leading solution. HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is aligned with the ETSI-NFV architecture.

section.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes two Linux host operating systems, server virtualization (KVM), network virtualization (vSwitch and SDN controllers), an installer and cloud lifecycle management framework, fault and performance management, and high-availability framework for the OpenStack control plane.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is based on HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 but with significantly enhanced and optimized functionality, availability, scale and performance to meet the needs of NFV cloud deployments.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes following key components:

ul.li: OpenStack—core services including Horizon, Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, Swift, Keystone, Ceilometer, and Heat.

Compute node software package that includes:
Carrier-grade Linux (host operating system [OS] running on the compute nodes)
Carrier-grade KVM (for virtualization of the compute node)
Carrier-grade virtual switch, data plane development kit (DPDK)-enabled high-performance virtual switch
Management and middleware—composed of high-availability (HA) management; operations, administration, and maintenance (OAM); software image management; and fault and performance management
Guest software development kit (SDK) for inclusion in the guest OS of the virtual network functions (VNF) for performance acceleration and improving the HA framework above and beyond standard VIMs.

body.section: Primary UsersTelecom companies desiring cloud-based Network Function Virtualization (NFV).

ul.li: Near-line rate networking throughout for VNFs like vEPC, vBRAS, vIMS, vFW, vRouter etc.
Advanced resource scheduling and orchestration capabilities
NIC Bonding at the server level
Compute Node failure detection and Auto-evacuation in the KVM region
Live Migration in the KVM region

section.title: Core HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Capabilities
section.p: Core capabilities unique to HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade include:

dd.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes a backup and restore application called Attis which you can use to backup and restore essential system files and components of the non-KVM cloud. Attis is automatically installed on each of the controller nodes in the non-KVM region. For more information, see Backup and Restore Configuration Files and MySQL Clusters.
For information on backing up and restoring the KVM region, see the KVM-Region Administrator Guide.
When launching a VM instance, you can specify multiple network interfaces.

The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Centralized Logging feature collects logs on a central system, rather than leaving the logs scattered across the network. The administrator can use a single Kibana interface to view log information in charts, graphs, tables, histograms, and other forms. For more information, see Centralized Logging.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade has four deployment models, depending on your system configuration. Specific installation templates are included in the download package to facilitate the deployment of your cloud.

You can find more information on the deployment options in the Technical Overview.
KVM-based cloud only (using the Denver template)
KVM with HP Distributed Cloud Networking (using the Tahoe template)
KVM + VMware ESX with DCN (using the Memphis template)
KVM + ESX + Ironic with DCN (using the Sacramento Deployment)
The currently supported version VMware vShpere ESX is .
You can integrate either HPE Storevirtual (VSA) or HP StoreServ (3PAR) storage in the KVM region.

ul.li:
With HPE StoreVirtual VSA storage
HPE StoreVirtual VSA software is a Virtual Storage Appliance that provides the complete array functionality on top of a Linux KVM environment without external hardware. VSA eliminates the need for external shared storage required to implement Block Storage features. The currently supported version of HPE StoreVirtual VSA is

With HPE StoreServ (3PAR) storage
HPE 3PAR StoreServ is a storage array that supports Fibre Channel (FC) as well as iSCSI protocol. The currently supported versions of HPE StoreServ (3PAR) are .

dd.p: You must install 3PAR or VSA before starting the HP Helion OpenStack installation and are independent of HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade.

When using the KVM + ESX + Ironic with DCN Topology, HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade leverages the OpenStack Ironic service, which aims to provision bare metal machines instead of virtual machines. For more information, see Ironic Service Overview.
The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation allows for network interface card bonding (bonded NIC).
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is comprised of a number of services, including several OpenStack and HP Helion OpenStack services.
For more information, see Services Overview.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade provides significantly improved network performance over the default OpenStack solution through a guest application on a virtual machine.
Virtual switching is a key function within data centers based on Software Defined Networking (SDN) as well as telecom infrastructures that leverages Network Functions Virtualization (NFV).

In the NFV scenario, for example, the virtual switch (vSwitch) is responsible for switching network traffic between the core network and the virtualized applications or Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) that are running in Virtual Machines (VMs). Based on your deployment model, you will use either:

HPE DCN Virtual Routing Switch (VRS). HP Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) is a Software-Defined Networking (SDN) solution that provides data center (DC) network virtualization and automatically establishes connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.

Leveraging programmable business logic and a powerful policy engine, the HP DCN provides an open and highly responsive solution that scales to meet the stringent needs of massive multi-tenant DCs. The HP DCN is a software solution that can be deployed over an existing DC IP network fabric. The main components in the HP DCN solution are: Virtualized Services Directory (VSD) and Virtualized Services Directory Architect (VSD-A), Virtualized Services Controller (VSC) and Virtual Routing and Switching (VRS). For more information on the DCN components, see DCN Components in the Support Matrix for the Tahoe, Memphis or Sacramento deployment.
VRS is included in the Tahoe, Memphis and Sacramento deployments of HP Helion Carrier Grade. The Technical Overview describes these deployments.

Accelerated vSwitch (AVS). AVS is integrated into the servers in the KVM region. AVS is an optimization of Open vSwitch (OVS) technology for NFV environments. Open vSwitch is a multilayer software switch licensed under the open source Apache 2 license. AVS provides connectivity between virtual machines on the same compute node, and between virtual machines and external networks. AVS is for customers who are focused on Virtualized Infrastructure Manager (VIM) key features like line rate performance and high availability.
AVS supports a variety of network connectivity options with the hosted virtual machines, as follows:

li.p: Unmodified guests can use Linux networking and virtio drivers. This provides a mechanism to bring existing applications into the production environment immediately.

Guest applications can be modified to leverage the Accelerated Virtual Port (AVP) drivers provided with the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade. AVP ports provide increased throughput over plain virtio drivers when connected to the AVS.

For the highest performance, guest applications can also be modified to make use of the Intel DPDK libraries and the AVP poll-mode drivers provided by the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade to connect with the AVS Switch.

dd.p: In addition to AVS, HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade incorporates DPDK-Accelerated Neutron Virtual Router L3 Forwarding (AVR). Accelerated forwarding is used between directly attached tenant networks and subnets, as well as for gateway, SNAT, and floating IP functionality.
AVS is included in the Denver deployment of HP Helion Carrier Grade. The Technical Overview describes these deployments.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade (in the KVM region) provides a number of extensions to OpenStack to deliver highly available hosting of virtual machines, including:
Automatic configuration of the OpenStack controller services in 1:1 active/standby mode across two controller nodes.

dlentry.dt: Fast detection of compute host failures

dd.p: Implemented by using a highly efficient and highly scalable heartbeat protocol between the controller and compute nodes.

dlentry.dt: Fast recovery of virtual machines instances upon detection of a compute node failure

dd.p: Extensions to Nova services that automatically re-schedule impacted virtual machine instances to available alternative compute nodes in the cluster.

dlentry.dt: Fast recovery of tenant network services upon detection of a compute node failure

dd.p: Extensions to Neutron that automatically re-schedule impacted network services such as DHCP, L3 Routing, and User/Meta data server, for all affected tenant networks. This covers tenant networks spanning multiple compute nodes.

dlentry.dt: Fast and enhanced detection of virtual machines failures

dd.p: Failure of any KVM/QEMU instance is automatically reported by the death process notification.

Additionally, modified guests can make use of the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Guest Heartbeat Library to register application-specific health check callbacks with the virtual machine. This registration allows Nova compute extensions on the host compute node to monitor the health of the guest application. The frequency of the health checks is determined at registration time. The semantics of the health check, that is, determining when the application is in a good or a bad state, is under the control of the application itself.

dlentry.dt: Automatic recovery of failed virtual machine instances

dd.p: Extensions to Nova that automatically re-start a failed virtual machine on the same compute node. If the re-start operation fails, the virtual machine is re-scheduled to use an alternative compute node.
Named groups of virtual machines instances to which a common set of attributes are applied, including:

li.p: maximum number of virtual machine instances
best effort or strict affinity policy

dd.p: Virtual machines in the same server group can use a server group messaging API for low-bandwidth communications.
In a typical use of a virtual machine server group, guest applications in active/standby pairs are deployed on different compute nodes to protect them from hardware failures.

dlentry.dt: Live migration support with DPDK-accelerated networking

dd.p: Live migration support for virtual machines using the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade high-performance networking options.

dlentry.dt: Graceful shutdown (and other operations) of virtual machines

dd.p: Nova extensions that turn the default shutdown operation of virtual machines into an ACPI shutdown. Guest applications can therefore register shutdown scripts using standard ACPI mechanisms to execute operations such as closing files, updating persistent databases, or cleanly disconnecting from subscribed services.

Optionally, guest applications can use the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Guest Heartbeat Library to register to receive process management requests such as shutdown, live-migrate, pause, auto-scale, and others. The guest applications can then reject the requests based upon application-specific state directives, or prepare for a graceful execution.
Support for LAG, also known as Aggregate Ethernet, on controller and compute nodes for link protection.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade HA middleware is protected by a process monitor that uses death process notification to detect and respawn critical HA processes.

The Ceilometer service in the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade features improved performance, scalability, and usability. It has been extended to support a CSV-formatted file backend that provides a more traditional Telco Northbound interface for performance management.
The OpenStack Heat orchestration service is enhanced to include:

li.p: Support for several missing resource types in the public reference implementation
Helpful example templates illustrating real reference scenarios

dd.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade provides an improved execution environment for virtual machines that contributes to their overall performance when deployed on the compute nodes in the KVM region. Enhancements to the execution environment include:

li.p: Low-latency, bounded delivery of virtual interrupts, and availability of low-latency high resolution timers.
Option to allocate 2 MB or 1 GB huge memory pages to reduce swapping and TLB lookup misses.
Improved resource tracking of VMs that use dedicated CPUs, to ensure successful migration and evacuation.
Support for affining guest NUMA nodes to specific host NUMA nodes.
Capability to specify specific CPU models to be used by a virtual machine in order to leverage advanced features of the CPU architecture.

dd.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade guests can make use of VLANs to encapsulate IP traffic from a single or multiple IP subnets on a virtual Ethernet interface. This capability facilitates the porting of current user applications running on dedicated physical servers using VLANs to a virtualized environment.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade tenants can define multiple IP subnets on a single tenant network, get their traffic encapsulated on VLAN IDs of their choice, and still benefit from the underlying functionality provided by the AVS and the overall virtualized network infrastructure.

You can connect a VM directly to a physical interface using PCI passthrough or SR-IOV. You can choose either method by selecting pci-sriov or pci-passthrough as the network type when creating interfaces.

PCI Passthrough. A passthrough Ethernet interface is a physical PCI Ethernet NIC on a compute node to which a virtual machine is granted direct access. This minimizes packet processing delays but at the same time demands special operational considerations. For all purposes, a PCI passthrough interface behaves as if it were physically attached to the virtual machine.
Instructions for configuring SR-IOV are available after for installation, see Configuring PCI-Passthrough

SR-IOV. A Single-Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) Ethernet interface is a physical PCI Ethernet NIC that implements hardware-based virtualization mechanisms to expose multiple virtual network interfaces that can be used by one or more virtual machines simultaneously.
Instructions for configuring SR-IOV are available after for installation, see Configuring SR-IOV.

A cloud orchestration service that monitors and manages the resource usage on the compute nodes to power down servers during periods of low usage. This service contributes to saving power and operational costs.

By continuously monitoring the resource usage, the power management service can de-fragment the service cloud by live-migrating virtual machine instances onto a smaller set of compute nodes. Unused hosts can then be manually powered down.
As the cloud usage levels rise, unused compute nodes can be manually powered on to host new virtual machine instances.
